web.title: OpenAI - Wikipedia
web.description: OpenAI is an American artificial intelligence (AI) organization headquartered in San Francisco, California. It aims to develop "safe and beneficial" artificial general intelligence (AGI), which it defines as "highly autonomous systems that outperform humans at most economically valuable work".

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Artificial intelligence research organization

Not to be confused with [OpenAL](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OpenAL "OpenAL"), [OpenAPI](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OpenAPI_(disambiguation) "OpenAPI (disambiguation)"), or [Open-source artificial intelligence](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open-source_artificial_intelligence "Open-source artificial intelligence").

**OpenAI** is an American [artificial intelligence](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence "Artificial intelligence") (AI) organization headquartered in [San Francisco, California](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco "San Francisco"). It aims to develop "safe and beneficial" [artificial general intelligence](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_general_intelligence "Artificial general intelligence") (AGI), which it defines as "highly autonomous systems that outperform humans at most economically valuable work".[\[7\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-OpenAI-2018-7) As a leading organization in the ongoing [AI boom](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AI_boom "AI boom"),[\[8\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-8) OpenAI is known for the [GPT](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generative_pre-trained_transformer "Generative pre-trained transformer") family of [large language models](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_language_model "Large language model"), the [DALL-E](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DALL-E "DALL-E") series of [text-to-image models](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Text-to-image_model "Text-to-image model"), and a [text-to-video model](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Text-to-video_model "Text-to-video model") named [Sora](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sora_(text-to-video_model) "Sora (text-to-video model)").[\[9\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-9)[\[10\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-10) Its release of [ChatGPT](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ChatGPT "ChatGPT") in November 2022 has been credited with catalyzing widespread interest in [generative AI](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generative_AI "Generative AI").

The organization has a complex corporate structure. As of October 2025, it is led by the [non-profit](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonprofit_organization "Nonprofit organization") OpenAI Foundation, founded in 2015 and [registered in Delaware](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delaware_General_Corporation_Law "Delaware General Corporation Law"), which holds a 26% equity stake in OpenAI Group PBC, a for-profit [public benefit corporation](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benefit_corporation "Benefit corporation") which commercializes its products.[\[11\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-St-11) [Microsoft](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft "Microsoft") invested over $13 billion into OpenAI,[\[12\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-Reuters_2025-12) and provides [Azure](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Azure "Microsoft Azure") cloud computing resources.[\[13\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-13) In October 2025, OpenAI conducted a $6.6 billion share sale that valued the company at $500 billion.[\[14\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-14) On 28 October 2025, OpenAI said it had converted its main business into a for-profit corporation, with Microsoft acquiring a 27% stake in the company and the remaining non-profit company (now known as the OpenAI Foundation) owning a 26% stake.[\[15\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-15)

In 2023 and 2024, OpenAI faced multiple lawsuits for alleged [copyright infringement](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Copyright_infringement "Copyright infringement") against authors and media companies whose work was used to train some of OpenAI's products. In November 2023, OpenAI's board [removed Sam Altman](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI "Removal of Sam Altman from OpenAI") as CEO, citing a lack of confidence in him, but reinstated him five days later following a reconstruction of the board. Throughout 2024, roughly half of then-employed [AI safety](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AI_safety "AI safety") researchers left OpenAI, citing the company's prominent role in an industry-wide problem.[\[16\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-16)[\[17\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-17)

## Founding

[![](http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Pioneer_Building%2C_San_Francisco_%282019%29_-1.jpg/250px-Pioneer_Building%2C_San_Francisco_%282019%29_-1.jpg)](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Pioneer_Building,_San_Francisco_(2019)_-1.jpg) Former headquarters at the [Pioneer Building](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pioneer_Building_(San_Francisco) "Pioneer Building (San Francisco)") in San Francisco

In December 2015, OpenAI was founded as a [not for profit organization](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonprofit_organization "Nonprofit organization") by [Sam Altman](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sam_Altman "Sam Altman"), [Elon Musk](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elon_Musk "Elon Musk"), [Ilya Sutskever](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ilya_Sutskever "Ilya Sutskever"), [Greg Brockman](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greg_Brockman "Greg Brockman"), [Trevor Blackwell](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trevor_Blackwell "Trevor Blackwell"), Vicki Cheung, [Andrej Karpathy](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrej_Karpathy "Andrej Karpathy"), Durk Kingma, [John Schulman](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Schulman "John Schulman"), Pamela Vagata, and [Wojciech Zaremba](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wojciech_Zaremba "Wojciech Zaremba"), with Sam Altman and Elon Musk as the co-chairs.[\[18\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-wired_inside-18)[\[19\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-19) A total of $1 billion in capital was pledged by Sam Altman, Greg Brockman, Elon Musk, [Reid Hoffman](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reid_Hoffman "Reid Hoffman"), [Jessica Livingston](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jessica_Livingston "Jessica Livingston"), [Peter Thiel](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Thiel "Peter Thiel"), [Amazon Web Services](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amazon_Web_Services "Amazon Web Services") (AWS), and [Infosys](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infosys "Infosys").[\[20\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-20)[\[21\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-21) The actual collected total amount of contributions was only $130 million until 2019.[\[11\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-St-11)

The organization stated it would "freely collaborate" with other institutions and researchers by making some of its patents and research open to the public.[\[22\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-22)[\[23\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-bbc-giants-23)[\[18\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-wired_inside-18) OpenAI was initially run from Brockman's living room.[\[24\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-24) It was later headquartered at the [Pioneer Building](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pioneer_Building_(San_Francisco) "Pioneer Building (San Francisco)") in the [Mission District, San Francisco](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mission_District,_San_Francisco "Mission District, San Francisco").[\[25\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-25)[\[26\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-technologyreview-26)

According to OpenAI's charter, its founding mission is "to ensure that artificial general intelligence (AGI)—by which we mean highly autonomous systems that outperform humans at most economically valuable work—benefits all of humanity."[\[7\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-OpenAI-2018-7)

Musk and Altman stated in 2015 that they were partly motivated by concerns about [AI safety](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AI_safety "AI safety") and [existential risk from artificial general intelligence](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Existential_risk_from_artificial_general_intelligence "Existential risk from artificial general intelligence").[\[27\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-csmonitor-27)[\[18\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-wired_inside-18) OpenAI stated that "it's hard to fathom how much human-level AI could benefit society", and that it is equally difficult to comprehend "how much it could damage society if built or used incorrectly".[\[23\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-bbc-giants-23) The startup also wrote that AI "should be an extension of individual human wills and, in the spirit of liberty, as broadly and evenly distributed as possible",[\[23\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-bbc-giants-23) and that "because of AI's surprising history, it's hard to predict when human-level AI might come within reach. When it does, it'll be important to have a leading research institution which can prioritize a good outcome for all over its own self-interest."[\[28\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-28) Co-chair Sam Altman expected a decades-long project that eventually surpasses human intelligence.[\[29\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-wired_far_more-29)

Brockman met with [Yoshua Bengio](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yoshua_Bengio "Yoshua Bengio"), one of the "founding fathers" of [deep learning](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_learning "Deep learning"), and drew up a list of great AI researchers.[\[18\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-wired_inside-18) Brockman was able to hire nine of them as the first employees in December 2015.[\[18\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-wired_inside-18) OpenAI did not pay AI researchers salaries comparable to those of [Facebook](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Facebook "Facebook") or [Google](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google "Google").[\[18\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-wired_inside-18) It also did not pay stock options which AI researchers typically get. Nevertheless, OpenAI spent $7 million on its first 52 employees in 2016.[\[30\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-salaryTimes-30) OpenAI's potential and mission drew these researchers to the firm; a Google employee said he was willing to leave Google for OpenAI "partly because of the very strong group of people and, to a very large extent, because of its mission."[\[18\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-wired_inside-18) OpenAI co-founder [Wojciech Zaremba](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wojciech_Zaremba "Wojciech Zaremba") stated that he turned down "borderline crazy" offers of two to three times his market value to join OpenAI instead.[\[18\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-wired_inside-18)

In April 2016, OpenAI released a public beta of "OpenAI Gym", its platform for [reinforcement learning](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning "Reinforcement learning") research.[\[31\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-Dave_Gershgorn-2016-31) [Nvidia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nvidia "Nvidia") gifted its first [DGX-1 supercomputer](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nvidia_DGX "Nvidia DGX") to OpenAI in August 2016 to help it train larger and more complex AI models with the capability of reducing processing time from six days to two hours.[\[32\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-32)[\[33\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-33) In December 2016, OpenAI released "Universe", a software platform for measuring and training an AI's general intelligence across the world's supply of games, websites, and other applications.[\[34\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-34)[\[35\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-35)[\[36\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-36)[\[37\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-37)

## Corporate structure

[![](http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/OpenAI_corporate_structure.svg/250px-OpenAI_corporate_structure.svg.png)](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:OpenAI_corporate_structure.svg) OpenAI's corporate structure

### Transition from non-profit

In 2019, OpenAI transitioned from non-profit to "capped" for-profit, with the profit being capped at 100 times any investment.[\[38\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-38) According to OpenAI, the capped-profit model allows OpenAI Global, LLC to legally attract investment from venture funds and, in addition, to grant employees stakes in the company.[\[39\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-wired_investors-39) Many top researchers work for [Google Brain](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_Brain "Google Brain"), [DeepMind](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DeepMind "DeepMind"), or [Facebook](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Facebook "Facebook"), which offer stock options that a nonprofit would be unable to.[\[40\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-bloomberg_arm-40) Before the transition, public disclosure of the compensation of top employees at OpenAI was legally required.[\[30\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-salaryTimes-30)

The company then distributed [equity](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equity_(finance) "Equity (finance)") to its employees and partnered with Microsoft,[\[41\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-2019investment-41) announcing an investment package of $1 billion into the company. Since then, OpenAI systems have run on an [Azure](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Azure "Microsoft Azure")-based [supercomputing](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supercomputer "Supercomputer") platform from Microsoft.[\[42\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-Langston_2023-42)[\[43\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-Foley_2020-43)[\[44\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-Engadget_2020-44)

OpenAI Global, LLC then announced its intention to commercially license its technologies.[\[45\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-45) It planned to spend $1 billion "within five years, and possibly much faster".[\[46\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-46) Altman stated that even a billion dollars may turn out to be insufficient, and that the lab may ultimately need "more capital than any non-profit has ever raised" to achieve artificial general intelligence.[\[47\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-47)

The nonprofit, OpenAI, Inc., is the sole [controlling shareholder](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Controlling_interest "Controlling interest") of OpenAI Global, LLC, which, despite being a for-profit company, retains a formal [fiduciary responsibility](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fiduciary_duty "Fiduciary duty") to OpenAI, Inc.'s nonprofit charter. A majority of OpenAI, Inc.'s board is barred from having financial stakes in OpenAI Global, LLC.[\[39\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-wired_investors-39) In addition, minority members with a stake in OpenAI Global, LLC are barred from certain votes due to conflict of interest.[\[40\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-bloomberg_arm-40) Some researchers have argued that OpenAI Global, LLC's switch to for-profit status is inconsistent with OpenAI's claims to be "democratizing" AI.[\[48\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-48)

On February 29, 2024, [Elon Musk](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elon_Musk "Elon Musk") filed a lawsuit against OpenAI and CEO Sam Altman, accusing them of shifting focus from public benefit to profit maximization—a case OpenAI dismissed as "incoherent" and "frivolous," though Musk later revived legal action against Altman and others in August.[\[49\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-49)[\[50\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-50)[\[51\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-51)[\[52\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-52)

On April 9, 2024, OpenAI countersued Musk in federal court, alleging that he had engaged in "bad-faith tactics" to slow the company's progress and seize its innovations for his personal benefit. OpenAI also argued that Musk had previously supported the creation of a for-profit structure and had expressed interest in controlling OpenAI himself. The countersuit seeks damages and legal measures to prevent further alleged interference.[\[53\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-53)

On February 10, 2025, a consortium of investors led by Elon Musk submitted a $97.4 billion unsolicited bid to buy the nonprofit that controls OpenAI, declaring willingness to match or exceed any better offer.[\[54\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-54)[\[55\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-Toonkel-2025-55) The offer was rejected on 14 February 2025, with OpenAI stating that it was not for sale,[\[56\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-56) but the offer complicated Altman's restructuring plan by suggesting a lower bar for how much the nonprofit should be valued.[\[55\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-Toonkel-2025-55)

OpenAI, Inc. was originally designed as a nonprofit in order to ensure that AGI "benefits all of humanity" rather than "the private gain of any person". In 2019, it created OpenAI Global, LLC, a capped-profit subsidiary controlled by the nonprofit. In December 2024, OpenAI proposed a restructuring plan to convert the capped-profit into a Delaware-based [public benefit corporation](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benefit_corporation "Benefit corporation") (PBC), and to release it from the control of the nonprofit. The nonprofit would sell its control and other assets, getting equity in return, and would use it to fund and pursue separate charitable projects, including in science and education. OpenAI's leadership described the change as necessary to secure additional investments, and claimed that the nonprofit's founding mission to ensure AGI "benefits all of humanity" would be better fulfilled.[\[57\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-57)

The plan has been criticized by former employees. A legal letter named "Not For Private Gain" asked the [attorneys general of California](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attorney_General_of_California "Attorney General of California") and [Delaware](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attorney_General_of_Delaware "Attorney General of Delaware") to intervene, stating that the restructuring is illegal and would remove governance safeguards from the nonprofit and the attorneys general.[\[58\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-58)[\[59\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-59) The letter argues that OpenAI's complex structure was deliberately designed to remain accountable to its mission, without the conflicting pressure of maximizing profits. It contends that the nonprofit is best positioned to advance its mission of ensuring AGI benefits all of humanity by continuing to control OpenAI Global, LLC, whatever the amount of equity that it could get in exchange.[\[60\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-Piper-2025-60) PBCs can choose how they balance their mission with profit-making. Controlling shareholders have a large influence on how closely a PBC sticks to its mission.[\[61\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-Reuters-2025-61)[\[60\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-Piper-2025-60)

#### 2025 restructuring

On October 28, 2025, OpenAI announced that it had adopted the new PBC corporate structure after receiving approval from the attorneys general of California and Delaware.[\[5\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-nyt-restructure-5) Under the new structure, OpenAI's for-profit branch became a public benefit corporation known as OpenAI Group PBC, while the non-profit was renamed to the OpenAI Foundation.[\[5\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-nyt-restructure-5)[\[62\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-reuters-restructure-62) The OpenAI Foundation holds a 26% stake in the PBC, while Microsoft holds a 27% stake and the remaining 47% is owned by employees and other investors.[\[5\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-nyt-restructure-5)[\[63\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-cnbc-restructure-63)

All members of the OpenAI Group PBC board of directors will be appointed by the OpenAI Foundation, which can remove them at any time.[\[5\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-nyt-restructure-5) Members of the Foundation's board will also serve on the for-profit board.[\[5\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-nyt-restructure-5) The new structure allows the for-profit PBC to raise investor funds like most traditional tech companies, including through an [initial public offering](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Initial_public_offering "Initial public offering"), which Altman claimed was the most likely path forward.[\[62\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-reuters-restructure-62)

### Partnership with Microsoft

In January 2023, OpenAI Global, LLC was in talks for funding that would value the company at $29 billion, double its 2021 value.[\[64\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-64) On January 23, 2023, Microsoft announced a new US$10 billion investment in OpenAI Global, LLC over multiple years, partially needed to use Microsoft's cloud-computing service _Azure_.[\[65\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-65)[\[66\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-66)

On September 21, 2023, Microsoft had begun rebranding all variants of its Copilot to [Microsoft Copilot](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Copilot "Microsoft Copilot"), including the former _Bing Chat_ and the _Microsoft 365 Copilot_.[\[67\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-unify-67) This strategy was followed in December 2023 by adding the MS-Copilot to many installations of [Windows 11](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_11 "Windows 11") and [Windows 10](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_10 "Windows 10") as well as a standalone _Microsoft Copilot app_ released for [Android](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Android_(operating_system) "Android (operating system)")[\[68\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-androidlaunch-68) and one released for [iOS](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IOS "IOS") thereafter.[\[69\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-ioslaunch-69)

Following OpenAI's 2025 restructuring, Microsoft owns a 27% stake in the for-profit OpenAI Group PBC, valued at $135 billion.[\[63\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-cnbc-restructure-63) In a deal announced the same day, OpenAI agreed to purchase $250 billion of Azure services, with Microsoft ceding their [right of first refusal](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Right_of_first_refusal "Right of first refusal") over OpenAI's future cloud computing purchases.[\[63\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-cnbc-restructure-63)[\[70\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-verge-restructure-70) As part of the deal, OpenAI will continue to share 20% of its revenue with Microsoft until it achieves AGI, which must now be verified by an independent panel of experts.[\[62\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-reuters-restructure-62)[\[70\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-verge-restructure-70) The deal also loosened restrictions on both companies working with third parties, allowing Microsoft to pursue AGI independently and allowing OpenAI to develop products with other companies.[\[63\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-cnbc-restructure-63)[\[5\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-nyt-restructure-5)[\[70\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-verge-restructure-70)

### Finances

![](http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Ambox_clock_yellow.svg/40px-Ambox_clock_yellow.svg.png)

This section **appears to be [slanted towards recent events](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Recentism "Wikipedia:Recentism").** Please try to keep recent events in historical perspective and [add more content](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=OpenAI&action=edit) related to non-recent events._(August 2025)_

In 2017, OpenAI spent $7.9 million, a quarter of its functional expenses, on cloud computing alone.[\[71\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-71) In comparison, [DeepMind](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DeepMind "DeepMind")'s total expenses in 2017 were $442 million. In the summer of 2018, training OpenAI's _Dota 2_ bots required renting 128,000 [CPUs](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_processing_unit "Central processing unit") and 256 [GPUs](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graphics_processing_unit "Graphics processing unit") from Google for multiple weeks.[\[39\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-wired_investors-39)

In October 2024, OpenAI completed a $6.6 billion capital raise with a $157 billion valuation including investments from Microsoft, Nvidia, and SoftBank.[\[72\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-72)

On January 21, 2025, [Donald Trump](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump") announced [The Stargate Project](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stargate_LLC "Stargate LLC"), a joint venture between OpenAI, [Oracle](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oracle_Corporation "Oracle Corporation"), [SoftBank](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SoftBank_Group "SoftBank Group") and [MGX](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MGX_(company) "MGX (company)") to build an AI infrastructure system in conjunction with the [US government](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States "Federal government of the United States"). The project takes its name from OpenAI's existing "Stargate" supercomputer project and is estimated to cost $500 billion. The partners plan to fund the project over the next four years.[\[73\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-73) In July, the [United States Department of Defense](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Defense "United States Department of Defense") announced that OpenAI had received a $200 million contract for AI in the military, along with Anthropic, Google, and [xAI](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XAI_(company) "XAI (company)").[\[74\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-74) In the same month, the company made a deal with the [UK Government](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UK_Government "UK Government") to use ChatGPT and other AI tools in public services.[\[75\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-75)[\[76\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-76) OpenAI subsequently began a $50 million fund to support nonprofit and community organizations.[\[77\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-77)

In April 2025, OpenAI raised $40 billion at a $300 billion post-money valuation, which was the highest-value private technology deal in history. The financing round was led by SoftBank, with other participants including Microsoft, [Coatue](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coatue_Management "Coatue Management"), [Altimeter](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altimeter_Capital "Altimeter Capital") and [Thrive](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thrive_Capital "Thrive Capital").[\[78\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-78)[\[79\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-79)

In July 2025, the company reported annualized revenue of $12 billion.[\[80\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-80)[\[81\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-81) This was an increase from $3.7 billion in 2024, which was driven by ChatGPT subscriptions, which reached 20 million paid subscribers by April 2025, up from 15.5 million at the end of 2024, alongside a rapidly expanding enterprise customer base that grew to five million business users.[\[82\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-82)[\[83\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-83)[\[84\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-84)

The company [cash burn](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burn_rate "Burn rate") remains high due to the intensive computational costs required to train and run large language models. It projects to lose $8 billion in 2025.[\[85\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-85)[\[86\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-86)

Looking ahead, OpenAI has revised upward its long-term spending projections, now expecting to burn approximately $115 billion through 2029—roughly $80 billion more than the company's previous estimates.[\[87\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-yahoo-87) The annual cash burn is projected to escalate significantly, with spending expected to reach $17 billion in 2026, $35 billion in 2027, and $45 billion in 2028.[\[88\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-ground_news-88)[\[89\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-89) These expenditures are primarily allocated toward expanding compute infrastructure, developing proprietary AI chips, constructing data centers, and funding intensive model training programs, with more than half of the spending through the end of the decade expected to support research-intensive compute for model training and development.[\[90\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-90)

The company's financial strategy reflects a strategy of prioritizing market expansion and technological advancement over near-term profitability, with OpenAI targeting cash flow positive operations by 2029 and projecting revenue of approximately $200 billion by 2030.[\[88\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-ground_news-88) This aggressive spending trajectory underscores both the enormous capital requirements of scaling cutting-edge AI technology and OpenAI's commitment to maintaining its position as a leader in the artificial intelligence industry.[\[91\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-91)

In October 2025, OpenAI completed an employee share sale of up to $10 billion to existing investors which valued the company at $500 billion. The deal values OpenAI as the most valuable privately owned company in the world—surpassing [SpaceX](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SpaceX "SpaceX") as the world's most valuable private company.[\[92\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-92)

### Firing of Altman

Further information: [Removal of Sam Altman from OpenAI](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI "Removal of Sam Altman from OpenAI")

[![](http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Sam_Altman_TechCrunch_SF_2019_Day_2_Oct_3_%28cropped%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/250px-Sam_Altman_TechCrunch_SF_2019_Day_2_Oct_3_%28cropped%29_%28cropped%29.jpg)](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Sam_Altman_TechCrunch_SF_2019_Day_2_Oct_3_(cropped)_(cropped).jpg) Sam Altman in 2019

On November 17, 2023, Sam Altman was removed as CEO when its board of directors (composed of [Helen Toner](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helen_Toner "Helen Toner"), [Ilya Sutskever](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ilya_Sutskever "Ilya Sutskever"), [Adam D'Angelo](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adam_D%27Angelo "Adam D'Angelo") and Tasha McCauley) cited a lack of confidence in him. Chief Technology Officer [Mira Murati](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mira_Murati "Mira Murati") took over as interim CEO. [Greg Brockman](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greg_Brockman "Greg Brockman"), the president of OpenAI, was also removed as chairman of the board[\[93\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-93)[\[94\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-guard-17nov2023-94) and resigned from the company's presidency shortly thereafter.[\[95\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-95) Three senior OpenAI researchers subsequently resigned: director of research and GPT-4 lead Jakub Pachocki, head of AI risk [Aleksander Mądry](http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Aleksander_M%C4%85dry&action=edit&redlink=1 "Aleksander Mądry (page does not exist)") \[ [pl](https://pl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksander_M%C4%85dry "pl:Aleksander Mądry")\], and researcher Szymon Sidor.[\[96\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-96)[\[97\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-97)

On November 18, 2023, there were reportedly talks of Altman returning as CEO amid pressure placed upon the board by investors such as Microsoft and [Thrive Capital](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thrive_Capital "Thrive Capital"), who objected to Altman's departure.[\[98\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-98) Although Altman himself spoke in favor of returning to OpenAI, he has since stated that he considered starting a new company and bringing former OpenAI employees with him if talks to reinstate him didn't work out.[\[99\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-99) The board members agreed "in principle" to resign if Altman returned.[\[100\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-100) On November 19, 2023, negotiations with Altman to return failed and Murati was replaced by [Emmett Shear](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emmett_Shear "Emmett Shear") as interim CEO.[\[101\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-101) The board initially contacted [Anthropic](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthropic "Anthropic") CEO [Dario Amodei](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dario_Amodei "Dario Amodei") (a former OpenAI executive) about replacing Altman, and proposed a [merger](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mergers_and_acquisitions "Mergers and acquisitions") of the two companies, but both offers were declined.[\[102\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-102)

On November 20, 2023, Microsoft CEO [Satya Nadella](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satya_Nadella "Satya Nadella") announced Altman and Brockman would be joining Microsoft to lead a new advanced AI research team, but added that they were still committed to OpenAI despite recent events.[\[103\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-103) Before the partnership with Microsoft was finalized, Altman gave the board another opportunity to negotiate with him.[\[104\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-104) About 738 of OpenAI's 770 employees, including Murati and Sutskever, signed an open letter stating they would quit their jobs and join Microsoft if the board did not rehire Altman and then resign.[\[105\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-105)[\[106\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-106) This prompted OpenAI investors to consider legal action against the board as well.[\[107\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-107) In response, OpenAI management sent an internal memo to employees stating that negotiations with Altman and the board had resumed and would take some time.[\[108\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-108)

On November 21, 2023, after continued negotiations, Altman and Brockman returned to the company in their prior roles along with a reconstructed board made up of new members [Bret Taylor](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bret_Taylor "Bret Taylor") (as chairman) and [Lawrence Summers](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lawrence_Summers "Lawrence Summers"), with D'Angelo remaining.[\[109\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-109)[\[110\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-110) Concerns about Altman's response to this development, specifically regarding the discovery's potential safety implications, were reportedly raised with the company's board shortly before Altman's firing.[\[111\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-Anna_Tong_2023_u135-111) On November 29, 2023, OpenAI announced that an anonymous Microsoft employee had joined the board as a non-voting member to observe the company's operations;[\[112\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-112) Microsoft resigned from the board in July 2024.[\[113\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-113)

In February 2024, the [Securities and Exchange Commission](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Securities_and_Exchange_Commission "Securities and Exchange Commission") subpoenaed OpenAI's internal communication to determine if Altman's alleged lack of candor misled investors.[\[114\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-114)

In 2024, following the temporary removal of Sam Altman and his return, many employees gradually left OpenAI, including most of the original leadership team and a significant number of AI safety researchers.[\[115\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-115)[\[116\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-116)

### Acquisitions

In August 2023, it was announced that OpenAI had acquired the [New York](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_City "New York City")-based start-up Global Illumination, a company that deploys AI to develop digital infrastructure and creative tools.[\[117\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-117)

In June 2024, OpenAI acquired Multi, a startup focused on remote collaboration.[\[118\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-118)

In March 2025, OpenAI reached a deal with [CoreWeave](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CoreWeave "CoreWeave") to acquire $350 million worth of CoreWeave shares and access to AI infrastructure, in return for $11.9 billion paid over five years. Microsoft was already CoreWeave's biggest customer in 2024.[\[119\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-ReuterCore-119) Alongside their other business dealings, OpenAI and Microsoft were renegotiating the terms of their partnership to facilitate a potential future [initial public offering](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Initial_public_offering "Initial public offering") by OpenAI, while ensuring Microsoft's continued access to advanced AI models.[\[12\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-Reuters_2025-12)

On May 21, OpenAI announced the $6.5 billion acquisition of [io](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Io_(company) "Io (company)"), an AI hardware start-up founded by former Apple designer [Jony Ive](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jony_Ive "Jony Ive") in 2024.[\[120\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-120)[\[121\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-121)[\[122\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-122)

In September 2025, OpenAI agreed to acquire the product testing startup Statsig for $1.1 billion in an all-stock deal and appointed Statsig's founding CEO [Vijaye Raji](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vijaye_Raji "Vijaye Raji") as OpenAI's chief technology officer of applications.[\[123\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-123) The company also announced development of an AI-driven hiring service designed to rival [LinkedIn](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LinkedIn "LinkedIn").[\[124\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-Verge-124)

OpenAI acquired personal finance app Roi in October 2025.[\[125\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-125)

In December 2025, it was announced OpenAI had agreed to acquire Neptune, an AI tooling startup that helps companies track and manage model training, for an undisclosed amount.[\[126\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-126)

### Corporate partnerships

For broader coverage of this topic, see [Content moderation and working conditions](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Content_moderation_and_working_conditions "Content moderation and working conditions").

OpenAI has been criticized for outsourcing the [annotation of data sets](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labeled_data "Labeled data") to [Sama](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sama_(company) "Sama (company)"), a company based in San Francisco that employed workers in [Kenya](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenya "Kenya"). These annotations were used to train an AI model to detect toxicity, which could then be used to [moderate toxic content](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Content_moderation "Content moderation"), notably from ChatGPT's training data and outputs. However, these pieces of text usually contained detailed descriptions of various types of violence, including sexual violence. The investigation uncovered that OpenAI began sending snippets of data to Sama as early as November 2021. The four Sama employees interviewed by _[Time](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_(magazine) "Time (magazine)")_ described themselves as mentally scarred. OpenAI paid Sama $12.50 per hour of work, and Sama was redistributing the equivalent of between $1.32 and $2.00 per hour post-tax to its annotators. Sama's spokesperson said that the $12.50 was also covering other implicit costs, among which were infrastructure expenses, quality assurance and management.[\[127\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-Time1-127)

OpenAI began collaborating with [Broadcom](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Broadcom "Broadcom") in 2024 to design a custom AI chip capable of both training and inference targeted for mass production in 2026 and to be manufactured by [TSMC](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TSMC "TSMC") in [3 nm](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/3_nm_process "3 nm process") node. This initiative intended to reduce OpenAI's dependence on Nvidia GPUs, which are costly and face high demand in the market.[\[128\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-128)[\[129\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-reuters-openai-broadcom-129)[\[130\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-ft-openai-broadcom-130)

In January 2024, [Arizona State University](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arizona_State_University "Arizona State University") purchased ChatGPT Enterprise in OpenAI's first deal with a university.[\[131\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-131)

In June 2024, [Apple Inc.](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apple_Inc. "Apple Inc.") signed a contract with OpenAI to integrate ChatGPT features into its products as part of its new [Apple Intelligence](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apple_Intelligence "Apple Intelligence") initiative.[\[132\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-132)[\[133\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-133)

In June 2025, OpenAI began renting [Google Cloud](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_Cloud_Platform "Google Cloud Platform")'s Tensor Processing Units ( [TPUs](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TPU_(computing) "TPU (computing)")) to support [ChatGPT](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ChatGPT "ChatGPT") and related services, marking its first meaningful use of non‑Nvidia AI chips.[\[134\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-134)

In September 2025, it was revealed that OpenAI signed a contract with Oracle to purchase $300 billion in computing power over the next five years.[\[135\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-135)

In September 2025, OpenAI and NVIDIA announced a partnership that included a potential deployment of at least 10 gigawatts of NVIDIA systems and a $100 billion investment from NVIDIA in OpenAI.[\[136\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-136)

In October 2025, OpenAI announced a multi-billion dollar deal with [AMD](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AMD "AMD").[\[137\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-137) OpenAI committed to purchasing six gigawatts worth of AMD chips, starting with the MI450. OpenAI will have the option to buy up to 160 million shares of AMD, about 10% of the company, depending on development, performance and share price targets.[\[138\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-138)

In December 2025, [Disney](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Walt_Disney_Company "The Walt Disney Company") said it would make a $1 billion investment in OpenAI, and signed a three-year licensing deal that will let users generate videos using Sora—Open AI's short-form AI video platform. More than 200 Disney, [Marvel](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Studios "Marvel Studios"), [Star Wars](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star_Wars "Star Wars") and [Pixar](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pixar "Pixar") characters will be available to OpenAI users.[\[139\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-139)

### Government contracting

OpenAI provides [LLMs](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_language_model "Large language model") to the [Artificial Intelligence Cyber Challenge](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DARPA_Prize_Competitions "DARPA Prize Competitions"), and to the [Advanced Research Projects Agency for Health](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advanced_Research_Projects_Agency_for_Health "Advanced Research Projects Agency for Health").[\[140\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-140) In October 2024, [The Intercept](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Intercept "The Intercept") revealed that OpenAI's tools are considered "essential" for [AFRICOM](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Africa_Command "United States Africa Command")'s mission and included in an "Exception to Fair Opportunity" contractual agreement between the [United States Department of Defense](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Defense "United States Department of Defense") and [Microsoft](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft "Microsoft").[\[141\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-intercept-africom-141) In December 2024, OpenAI said it would partner with defense-tech company [Anduril](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anduril_Industries "Anduril Industries") to build drone defense technologies for the United States and its allies.[\[142\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-142)

In 2025, OpenAI's Chief Product Officer, Kevin Weil, was commissioned [lieutenant colonel](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lieutenant_colonel "Lieutenant colonel") in the [U.S. Army](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Army "United States Army") to join [Detachment 201](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Detachment_201 "Detachment 201") as senior advisor.[\[143\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-143)

In June 2025, the U.S. Department of Defense awarded OpenAI a $200 million one-year contract to develop AI tools for military and national security applications. OpenAI announced a new program, OpenAI for Government, to give federal, state, and local governments access to its models, including ChatGPT.[\[144\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-144)[\[145\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-145)

### Development

In February 2019, [GPT-2](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GPT-2 "GPT-2") was announced, which gained attention for its ability to generate human-like text.[\[146\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-guardian-146)

In 2020, OpenAI announced [GPT-3](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GPT-3 "GPT-3"), a language model trained on large internet datasets. GPT-3 is aimed at natural language answering questions, but it can also translate between languages and coherently generate improvised text. It also announced that an associated API, named _the API_, would form the heart of its first commercial product.[\[147\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-2020-06-11_Bloomberg-147)

Eleven employees left OpenAI, mostly between December 2020 and January 2021, in order to establish [Anthropic](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthropic "Anthropic").[\[148\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-148)

In 2021, OpenAI introduced [DALL-E](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DALL-E "DALL-E"), a specialized deep learning model adept at generating complex digital images from textual descriptions, utilizing a variant of the GPT-3 architecture.[\[149\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-149)

[![](http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/UK_national_football_team_considering_compete_in_UEFA_Euro_and_FIFA_World_Cup_%E2%80%93_ChatGPT.jpg/250px-UK_national_football_team_considering_compete_in_UEFA_Euro_and_FIFA_World_Cup_%E2%80%93_ChatGPT.jpg)](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:UK_national_football_team_considering_compete_in_UEFA_Euro_and_FIFA_World_Cup_%E2%80%93_ChatGPT.jpg) The release of [ChatGPT](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ChatGPT "ChatGPT") was a major event in the [AI boom](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AI_boom "AI boom"). By January 2023, ChatGPT had become what was then the fastest-growing consumer software application in history, gaining over 100 million users in two months.[\[150\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-150)

In December 2022, OpenAI received widespread media coverage after launching a free preview of [ChatGPT](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ChatGPT "ChatGPT"), its new AI [chatbot](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chatbot "Chatbot") based on GPT-3.5. According to OpenAI, the preview received over a million signups within the first five days.[\[151\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-151) According to anonymous sources cited by [Reuters](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reuters "Reuters") in December 2022, OpenAI Global, LLC was projecting $200 million of revenue in 2023 and $1 billion in revenue in 2024.[\[152\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-152)

Google announced a similar AI application ( [Bard](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bard_(chatbot) "Bard (chatbot)")), after ChatGPT was launched, fearing that ChatGPT could threaten Google's place as a go-to source for information.[\[153\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-153)[\[154\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-154)

On February 7, 2023, Microsoft announced that it was building AI technology based on the same foundation as ChatGPT into [Microsoft Bing](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Bing "Microsoft Bing"), [Edge](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Edge "Microsoft Edge"), [Microsoft 365](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_365 "Microsoft 365") and other products.[\[155\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-155)

On March 14, 2023, OpenAI released [GPT-4](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GPT-4 "GPT-4"), both as an API (with a waitlist) and as a feature of ChatGPT Plus.[\[156\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-156)

On November 6, 2023, OpenAI launched GPTs, allowing individuals to create customized versions of ChatGPT for specific purposes, further expanding the possibilities of AI applications across various industries.[\[157\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-157) On November 14, 2023, OpenAI announced they temporarily suspended new sign-ups for ChatGPT Plus due to high demand.[\[158\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-158) Access for newer subscribers re-opened a month later on December 13.[\[159\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-159)

In December 2024, the company launched the [Sora](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sora_(text-to-video_model) "Sora (text-to-video model)") model.[\[160\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-160)[\[161\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-161) It also launched [OpenAI o1](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OpenAI_o1 "OpenAI o1"), an early [reasoning model](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reasoning_model "Reasoning model") that was internally codenamed _strawberry_.[\[162\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-162) Additionally, ChatGPT Pro—a $200/month subscription service offering unlimited o1 access and enhanced voice features—was introduced, and preliminary benchmark results for the upcoming [OpenAI o3](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OpenAI_o3 "OpenAI o3") models were shared.[\[163\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-163)

On January 23, 2025, OpenAI released _Operator_, an [AI agent](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AI_agent "AI agent") and web automation tool for accessing websites to execute goals defined by users. The feature was only available to Pro users in the United States.[\[164\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-164)[\[165\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-165) OpenAI released [deep research agent](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ChatGPT_Deep_Research "ChatGPT Deep Research"), nine days later. It scored a 27% accuracy on the benchmark [Humanity's Last Exam](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humanity%27s_Last_Exam "Humanity's Last Exam") (HLE).[\[166\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-Verge_20250203-166) Altman later stated GPT-4.5 would be the last model without full chain-of-thought reasoning.[\[167\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-giz2-167)[\[168\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-fort3-168)

In July 2025, reports indicated that AI models by both OpenAI and [Google DeepMind](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_DeepMind "Google DeepMind") solved mathematics problems at the level of top-performing students in the [International Mathematical Olympiad](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Mathematical_Olympiad "International Mathematical Olympiad"). OpenAI's large language model was able to achieve gold medal-level performance, reflecting significant progress in AI's reasoning abilities.[\[169\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-nature-maths-169)

In September 2025, OpenAI released a first-of-its-kind study revealing how people use ChatGPT for everyday tasks.[\[170\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-170)[\[171\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-171) The study found that "non-work tasks" (according to an LLM-based classifier) account for more than 72 percent of all ChatGPT usage, with a minority of overall usage related to business productivity.[\[172\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-172)

On October 6, OpenAI unveiled its Agent Builder platform during the company's DevDay event. The platform features a drag-and-drop visual interface that allows developers and businesses to design, test, and deploy agentic workflows without requiring extensive coding expertise.[\[173\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-173)

On October 21 2025, OpenAI introduced [ChatGPT Atlas](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ChatGPT_Atlas "ChatGPT Atlas"), a browser integrating the ChatGPT assistant directly into web navigation, to compete with existing browsers such as [Google Chrome](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_Chrome "Google Chrome") and Apple [Safari](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Safari_(web_browser) "Safari (web browser)").[\[174\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-174)[\[175\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-175)[\[176\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-176)

On 11 December 2025, OpenAI announced GPT-5.2. This model will be better at creating spreadsheets, building presentations, perceiving images, writing code and understanding long context.[\[177\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-177)

### Transparency

In March 2023, the company was criticized for disclosing particularly few technical details about products like GPT-4, contradicting its initial commitment to openness and making it harder for independent researchers to replicate its work and develop safeguards. OpenAI cited competitiveness and safety concerns to justify this strategic turn. OpenAI's former chief scientist Ilya Sutskever argued in 2023 that open-sourcing increasingly capable models was increasingly risky, and that the safety reasons for not open-sourcing the most potent AI models would become "obvious" in a few years.[\[178\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-178)

### Alignment

In July 2023, OpenAI launched the superalignment project, aiming to find within 4 years how to [align](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AI_alignment "AI alignment") future superintelligences by automating alignment research using AI.[\[179\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-179) OpenAI promised to dedicate 20% of its computing resources to the project, although the team denied receiving anything close to 20%.[\[180\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-180) OpenAI ended the project in May 2024 after its co-leaders [Ilya Sutskever](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ilya_Sutskever "Ilya Sutskever") and [Jan Leike](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jan_Leike "Jan Leike") left the company.[\[181\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-181)

### Leaked conversations

In August 2025, OpenAI was criticized after thousands of private ChatGPT conversations were inadvertently exposed to public search engines like Google due to an experimental "share with search engines" feature. The opt-in toggle, intended to allow users to make specific chats discoverable, resulted in some discussions including personal details such as names, locations, and intimate topics appearing in search results when users accidentally enabled it while sharing links. OpenAI announced the feature's permanent removal on August 1, 2025, and the company began coordinating with search providers to remove the exposed content, emphasizing that it was not a security breach but a design flaw that heightened privacy risks. CEO Sam Altman acknowledged the issue in a podcast, noting users often treat ChatGPT as a confidant for deeply personal matters, which amplified concerns about AI handling sensitive data.[\[182\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-182)[\[183\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-183)[\[184\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-184)

### Personnel changes

In 2018, Musk resigned from his Board of Directors seat, citing "a potential future [conflict \[of interest\]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conflict_of_interest "Conflict of interest")" with his role as CEO of [Tesla](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tesla,_Inc. "Tesla, Inc.") due to Tesla's [AI development for self-driving cars.](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tesla_Autopilot "Tesla Autopilot")[\[197\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-musk_resigns-197) OpenAI stated that Musk's financial contributions were below $45 million.[\[198\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-198)

On March 3, 2023, [Reid Hoffman](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reid_Hoffman "Reid Hoffman") resigned from his board seat, citing a desire to avoid conflicts of interest with his investments in AI companies via [Greylock Partners](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greylock_Partners "Greylock Partners"), and his co-founding of the AI startup [Inflection AI](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inflection_AI "Inflection AI"). Hoffman remained on the board of Microsoft, a major investor in OpenAI.[\[199\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-199)

In May 2024, Chief Scientist [Ilya Sutskever](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ilya_Sutskever "Ilya Sutskever") resigned and was succeeded by [Jakub Pachocki](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jakub_Pachocki "Jakub Pachocki"). Co-leader [Jan Leike](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jan_Leike "Jan Leike") also departed amid concerns over safety and trust.[\[186\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-may14-186)[\[200\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-200) OpenAI then signed deals with [Reddit](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reddit "Reddit"), [News Corp](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/News_Corp "News Corp"), [Axios](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Axios_(website) "Axios (website)"), and [Vox Media](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vox_Media "Vox Media").[\[201\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-201)[\[202\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-202) [Paul Nakasone](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Nakasone "Paul Nakasone") then joined the board of OpenAI.[\[203\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-203)

In August 2024, cofounder John Schulman left OpenAI to join [Anthropic](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthropic "Anthropic"), and OpenAI's president [Greg Brockman](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greg_Brockman "Greg Brockman") took extended leave until November.[\[204\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-204)[\[205\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-205)

In September 2024, CTO [Mira Murati](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mira_Murati "Mira Murati") left the company.[\[206\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-206)[\[207\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-207)

In November 2025, [Lawrence Summers](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lawrence_Summers "Lawrence Summers") resigned from the board of directors.[\[208\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-208)

## Governance and legal issues

[![](http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Ilya_Sutskever_and_Sam_Altman_in_TAU.jpg/250px-Ilya_Sutskever_and_Sam_Altman_in_TAU.jpg)](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Ilya_Sutskever_and_Sam_Altman_in_TAU.jpg) Altman and Sutskever at [Tel Aviv University](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tel_Aviv_University "Tel Aviv University") in 2023

In May 2023, Sam Altman, Greg Brockman and Ilya Sutskever posted recommendations for the governance of [superintelligence](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superintelligence "Superintelligence").[\[209\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-OpenAI-Governance-209) They stated that superintelligence could happen within the next 10 years, allowing a "dramatically more prosperous future" and that "given the possibility of existential risk, we can't just be reactive". They proposed creating an international watchdog organization similar to [IAEA](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Atomic_Energy_Agency "International Atomic Energy Agency") to oversee AI systems above a certain capability threshold, suggesting that relatively weak AI systems on the other side should not be overly regulated. They also called for more technical safety research for superintelligences, and asked for more coordination, for example through governments launching a joint project which "many current efforts become part of".[\[209\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-OpenAI-Governance-209)[\[210\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-210)

In July 2023, the [FTC](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Trade_Commission "Federal Trade Commission") issued a [civil investigative demand](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civil_investigative_demand "Civil investigative demand") to OpenAI to investigate whether the company's [data security](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_security "Data security") and [privacy](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_privacy "Information privacy") practices to develop [ChatGPT](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ChatGPT "ChatGPT") were [unfair](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unfair_business_practices "Unfair business practices") or [harmed consumers](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consumer_protection "Consumer protection") (including by [reputational harm](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Defamation "Defamation")) in violation of Section 5 of the [Federal Trade Commission Act of 1914](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Trade_Commission_Act_of_1914 "Federal Trade Commission Act of 1914").[\[211\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-211)[\[212\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-212)[\[213\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-cnbcLeak1-213) These are typically preliminary investigative matters and are nonpublic, but the FTC's document was leaked.[\[214\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-214)[\[213\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-cnbcLeak1-213) In July 2023, the FTC launched an investigation into OpenAI over allegations that the company scraped public data and published false and defamatory information. They asked OpenAI for comprehensive information about its technology and privacy safeguards, as well as any steps taken to prevent the recurrence of situations in which its chatbot generated false and derogatory content about people.[\[215\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-215) The agency then reported concern with circular spending in which, for example, Microsoft gives OpenAI credit to [Microsoft Azure](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Azure "Microsoft Azure") and the companies provide each other access to engineering talent was of particular concern for its potential negative impacts to the public.[\[216\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-bloom1AIMicro-216)

In September 2024, OpenAI's global affairs chief endorsed the UK's "smart" AI regulation during testimony to a [House of Lords](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/House_of_Lords "House of Lords") committee.[\[217\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-217)

In February 2025, OpenAI CEO [Sam Altman](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sam_Altman "Sam Altman") stated that the company is interested in collaborating with the [People's Republic of China](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_China "People's Republic of China"), despite [regulatory restrictions imposed by the U.S. government](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_sanctions_against_China "United States sanctions against China").[\[218\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-218) This shift comes in response to the growing influence of the Chinese artificial intelligence company [DeepSeek](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DeepSeek "DeepSeek"), which has disrupted the AI market with open models, including DeepSeek V3 and DeepSeek R1.[\[219\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-219)[\[220\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-220) In response to DeepSeek, OpenAI overhauled its security operations to better guard against [industrial espionage](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_espionage "Industrial espionage"), particularly amid allegations that DeepSeek had improperly copied OpenAI's [distillation](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knowledge_distillation "Knowledge distillation") techniques.[\[221\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-221)

According to Oliver Roberts, in March 2025, the United States had 781 state AI bills or laws. OpenAI advocated for [preempting](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_preemption "Federal preemption") state AI laws with federal laws.[\[222\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-roberts2025-222) According to Scott Kohler, OpenAI has opposed California's AI legislation and suggested that the state bill encroaches on a more competent federal government.[\[223\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-223) [Public Citizen](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_Citizen "Public Citizen") opposed a federal preemption on AI and pointed to OpenAI's growth and valuation as evidence that existing state laws have not hampered [innovation](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Innovation "Innovation").[\[224\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-224)

### Non-disparagement agreements

Before May 2025, OpenAI required departing employees to sign a lifelong [non-disparagement agreement](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-disclosure_agreement "Non-disclosure agreement") forbidding them from criticizing OpenAI and acknowledging the existence of the agreement. [Daniel Kokotajlo](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_Kokotajlo_(researcher) "Daniel Kokotajlo (researcher)"), a former employee, publicly stated that he forfeited his vested equity in OpenAI in order to leave without signing the agreement.[\[225\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-225)[\[226\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-226) Sam Altman stated that he was unaware of the equity cancellation provision, and that OpenAI never enforced it to cancel any employee's vested equity.[\[227\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-227) However, leaked documents and emails refute this claim.[\[228\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-228) On May 23, 2024, OpenAI sent a memo releasing former employees from the agreement.[\[229\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-229)

### Copyright

OpenAI was sued for [copyright infringement](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Copyright_infringement "Copyright infringement") by authors [Sarah Silverman](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarah_Silverman "Sarah Silverman"), [Matthew Butterick](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matthew_Butterick "Matthew Butterick"), [Paul Tremblay](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_G._Tremblay "Paul G. Tremblay") and [Mona Awad](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mona_Awad "Mona Awad") in July 2023.[\[230\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-230)[\[231\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-Krithika-2023-231)[\[232\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-232) In September 2023, 17 authors, including [George R. R. Martin](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_R._R._Martin "George R. R. Martin"), [John Grisham](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Grisham "John Grisham"), [Jodi Picoult](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jodi_Picoult "Jodi Picoult") and [Jonathan Franzen](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jonathan_Franzen "Jonathan Franzen"), joined the [Authors Guild](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authors_Guild "Authors Guild") in filing a class action lawsuit against OpenAI, alleging that the company's technology was illegally using their copyrighted work.[\[233\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-233)[\[234\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-234) The _[New York Times](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Times "New York Times")_ also sued the company in late December 2023.[\[231\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-Krithika-2023-231)[\[235\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-235) In May 2024 it was revealed that OpenAI had destroyed its Books1 and Books2 training datasets, which were used in the [training of GPT-3](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GPT-3#Training_and_capabilities "GPT-3"), and which the Authors Guild believed to have contained over 100,000 copyrighted books.[\[236\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-236)

In 2021, OpenAI developed a [speech recognition](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speech_recognition "Speech recognition") tool called Whisper. OpenAI used it to transcribe more than one million hours of YouTube videos into text for training GPT-4. The automated transcription of YouTube videos raised concerns within OpenAI employees regarding potential violations of YouTube's terms of service, which prohibit the use of videos for applications independent of the platform, as well as any type of automated access to its videos. Despite these concerns, the project proceeded with notable involvement from OpenAI's president, [Greg Brockman](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greg_Brockman "Greg Brockman"). The resulting dataset proved instrumental in training GPT-4.[\[237\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-237)

In February 2024, _[The Intercept](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Intercept "The Intercept")_ as well as _[Raw Story](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raw_Story "Raw Story")_ and Alternate Media Inc. filed lawsuit against OpenAI on copyright litigation ground.[\[238\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-238)[\[239\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-239) The lawsuit is said to have charted a new legal strategy for digital-only publishers to sue OpenAI.[\[240\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-240)

On April 30, 2024, eight newspapers filed a lawsuit in the [Southern District of New York](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Attorney_for_the_Southern_District_of_New_York "United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York") against OpenAI and Microsoft, claiming illegal harvesting of their copyrighted articles. The suing publications included _[The Mercury News](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Mercury_News "The Mercury News")_, _[The Denver Post](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Denver_Post "The Denver Post")_, _[The Orange County Register](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Orange_County_Register "The Orange County Register")_, _[St. Paul Pioneer Press](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._Paul_Pioneer_Press "St. Paul Pioneer Press")_, _[Chicago Tribune](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago_Tribune "Chicago Tribune")_, _[Orlando Sentinel](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orlando_Sentinel "Orlando Sentinel")_, _[Sun Sentinel](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sun_Sentinel "Sun Sentinel")_, and _[New York Daily News](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Daily_News "New York Daily News")_.[\[241\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-ebt-30apr2024-241)

In June 2023, a lawsuit claimed that OpenAI [scraped](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_scraping "Web scraping") 300 billion words online without consent and without registering as a data broker. It was filed in [San Francisco](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco "San Francisco"), [California](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California "California"), by sixteen anonymous plaintiffs.[\[242\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-242) They also claimed that OpenAI and its partner as well as customer [Microsoft](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft "Microsoft") continued to unlawfully collect and use personal data from millions of consumers worldwide to train artificial intelligence models.[\[243\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-243)

On May 22, 2024, OpenAI entered into an agreement with [News Corp](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/News_Corp "News Corp") to integrate news content from _[The Wall Street Journal](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal "The Wall Street Journal")_, the _[New York Post](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Post "New York Post")_, _[The Times](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Times "The Times")_, and _[The Sunday Times](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Sunday_Times "The Sunday Times")_ into its AI platform. Meanwhile, other publications like _[The New York Times](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York Times")_ chose to sue OpenAI and [Microsoft](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft "Microsoft") for copyright infringement over the use of their content to train AI models.[\[244\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-244) In November 2024, a coalition of Canadian news outlets, including the [Toronto Star](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toronto_Star "Toronto Star"), [Metroland Media](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metroland_Media_Group "Metroland Media Group"), [Postmedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Postmedia_Network "Postmedia Network"), [The Globe and Mail](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Globe_and_Mail "The Globe and Mail"), [The Canadian Press](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Canadian_Press "The Canadian Press") and [CBC](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBC_News "CBC News"), sued OpenAI for using their news articles to train its software without permission.[\[245\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-245)

In October 2024 during a New York Times interview, [Suchir Balaji](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suchir_Balaji "Suchir Balaji") accused OpenAI of violating copyright law in developing its commercial LLMs which he had helped engineer. He was a likely witness in a major copyright trial against the AI company, and was one of several of its current or former employees named in court filings as potentially having documents relevant to the case. On November 26, 2024, Balaji shot himself dead. His death led to [conspiracy theories](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conspiracy_theories "Conspiracy theories") suggesting he had been deliberately silenced.[\[246\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-sf-standard-246)[\[247\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-Mercury-jan-31-247) California Congressman [Ro Khanna](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ro_Khanna "Ro Khanna") endorsed calls for an investigation.[\[248\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-rokhanna-248)[\[249\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-sfexaminer-jan-23-249)

### GDPR compliance

In April 2023, the EU's [European Data Protection Board](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Data_Protection_Board "European Data Protection Board") (EDPB) formed a dedicated task force on ChatGPT "to foster cooperation and to exchange information on possible enforcement actions conducted by data protection authorities" based on the "enforcement action undertaken by the Italian data protection authority against OpenAI about the ChatGPT service".[\[250\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-250)

In late April 2024 [NOYB](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NOYB "NOYB") filed a complaint with the [Austrian](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Austria "Austria") Datenschutzbehörde against OpenAI for violating the European [General Data Protection Regulation](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_Data_Protection_Regulation "General Data Protection Regulation"). A text created with ChatGPT gave a false [date of birth](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Date_of_birth "Date of birth") for a living person without giving the individual the option to see the personal data used in the process. A request to correct the mistake was denied. Additionally, neither the recipients of ChatGPT's work nor the sources used, could be made available, OpenAI claimed.[\[251\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-251)

### Military and warfare

OpenAI was criticized for lifting its ban on using ChatGPT for "military and warfare". Up until January 10, 2024, its "usage policies" included a ban on "activity that has high risk of physical harm, including", specifically, "weapons development" and "military and warfare". Its new policies prohibit "\[using\] our service to harm yourself or others" and to "develop or use weapons".[\[252\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-252)[\[253\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-253)

### Wrongful-death lawsuits over ChatGPT safety (2025)

Main article: [Raine v. OpenAI](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raine_v._OpenAI "Raine v. OpenAI")

See also: [Deaths linked to chatbots](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deaths_linked_to_chatbots "Deaths linked to chatbots")

In August 2025, the parents of a 16-year-old boy who died by suicide filed a [wrongful death lawsuit](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wrongful_death_claim "Wrongful death claim") against OpenAI (and CEO Sam Altman), alleging that months of conversations with ChatGPT about mental health and methods of self-harm contributed to their son's death and that safeguards were inadequate for minors. OpenAI expressed condolences and said it was strengthening protections (including updated crisis response behavior and parental controls). Coverage described it as a first-of-its-kind wrongful death case targeting the company's chatbot. The complaint was filed in California state court in San Francisco.[\[254\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-254)

In November 2025, the Social Media Victims Law Center and Tech Justice Law Project filed seven lawsuits against OpenAI, of which four lawsuits alleged wrongful death.[\[255\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-255) The suits were filed on behalf of [Zane Shamblin](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deaths_linked_to_chatbots#Suicide_of_Zane_Shamblin "Deaths linked to chatbots"), 23, of Texas; [Amaurie Lacey](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deaths_linked_to_chatbots#Suicide_of_Amaurie_Lacey "Deaths linked to chatbots"), 17, of Georgia; [Joshua Enneking](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deaths_linked_to_chatbots#Suicide_of_Joshua_Enneking "Deaths linked to chatbots"), 26, of Florida; and [Joe Ceccanti](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deaths_linked_to_chatbots#Suicide_of_Joe_Ceccanti "Deaths linked to chatbots"), 48, of Oregon, who each committed suicide after prolonged ChatGPT usage.[\[256\]](http://en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-256)

## About us

OpenAI is an AI research and deployment company dedicated to ensuring that general-purpose artificial intelligence benefits all of humanity. AI is an extremely powerful tool that must be created with safety and human needs at its core. OpenAI is dedicated to putting that alignment of interests first — ahead of profit.

To achieve our mission, we must encompass and value the many different perspectives, voices, and experiences that form the full spectrum of humanity. Our investment in diversity, equity, and inclusion is ongoing, executed through a wide range of initiatives, and championed and supported by leadership.

At OpenAI, we believe artificial intelligence has the potential to help people solve immense global challenges, and we want the upside of AI to be widely shared. Join us in shaping the future of technology.

We shipped Sora for Android in 28 days using the exact same assistant available to any team: Codex.

As our models grow more capable in cybersecurity, we’re taking a deliberate, long-term approach to safety and preparedness. We’re strengthening safeguards and working closely with global experts as we prepare for upcoming models to reach ‘High’ capability under our Preparedness Framework.

Cybersecurity is inherently dual-use, so we design for defenders first. We’re investing in layered protections—from training and access controls to monitoring, detection, and enforcement. At the same time, we’re expanding ecosystem efforts like trusted access programs, Aardvark, expert advisory councils, and sharing threat modeling with other frontier labs. These partnerships ensure safeguards reflect real-world needs and that insights move quickly across the security community.

We see this work as a sustained, long-term investment in giving defenders an advantage and continually strengthening the security posture of the critical infrastructure across the broader ecosystem.

Those notes turned into a longform essay, One Year With ChatGPT Pro as a First Hire. In a new proof-of-concept study, we’ve trained a GPT-5 Thinking variant to admit whether the model followed instructions. This “confessions” method surfaces hidden failures—guessing, shortcuts, rule-breaking—even when the final answer looks correct.

If we can surface when that happens, we can better monitor deployed systems, improve training, and increase trust in the outputs.

Confessions don’t prevent mistakes; they make them visible. Next, we’re scaling the approach and combining it with other alignment layers—like chain-of-thought monitoring, instruction hierarchy, and deliberative methods—to improve transparency and predictability as capabilities and stakes increase.
